extracted_concepts.definition: A collection of deities representing a fantasy interpretation of ancient Celtic religions, providing options for divine characters in Dungeons & Dragons. These gods are often revered by druids and clerics who align with nature.

rule_logic.premise: A D&D campaign incorporates fantasy-historical pantheons.
rule_logic.implication: The Celtic Pantheon, including its specific deities, alignments, domains, and symbols, is available for player character choices and world-building.
rule_logic.description_text: The Celtic, Egyptian, Greek, and Norse pantheons are fantasy interpretations of historical religions from our world's ancient times. They include deities that are most appropriate for use in a game, divorced from their historical context in the real world and united into pantheons that serve the needs of the game. The Celtic gods are as often served by druids as by clerics, for they are closely aligned with the forces of nature that druids revere.

extracted_concepts.definition: The Celtic god of weather and crops, aligned Chaotic Good (CG), with suggested domains of Nature and Trickery. Symbolized by a bubbling cauldron or shield.

rule_logic.premise: A D&D character chooses The Daghdha as their patron deity from the Celtic Pantheon.
rule_logic.implication: The character's chosen deity is The Daghdha, who is Chaotic Good, associated with Nature and Trickery domains, and represented by a bubbling cauldron or shield.
rule_logic.description_text: The Daghdha, god of weather and crops | CG | Nature, Trickery | Bubbling cauldron or shield

extracted_concepts.definition: A collection of deities representing a fantasy interpretation of ancient Greek religions, embodying natural phenomena and human qualities, available for divine characters in Dungeons & Dragons.

rule_logic.premise: A D&D campaign incorporates fantasy-historical pantheons.
rule_logic.implication: The Greek Pantheon, including its specific deities, alignments, domains, and symbols, is available for player character choices and world-building.
rule_logic.description_text: The gods of Olympus make themselves known with the gentle lap of waves against the shores and the crash of the thunder among the cloud-enshrouded peaks. The thick boar-infested woods and the sere, olive-covered hillsides hold evidence of their passing. Every aspect of nature echoes with their presence, and they've made a place for themselves inside the human heart, too.

extracted_concepts.definition: A collection of deities representing a fantasy interpretation of ancient Egyptian religions, focused on maintaining Ma'at (truth, justice, law, order) and governing the cosmos. Notable for having multiple gods associated with death.

rule_logic.premise: A D&D campaign incorporates fantasy-historical pantheons.
rule_logic.implication: The Egyptian Pantheon, including its specific deities, alignments, domains, and symbols, is available for player character choices and world-building. Special note on the varying alignments for death gods.
rule_logic.description_text: These gods are a young dynasty of an ancient divine family, heirs to the rulership of the cosmos and the maintenance of the divine principle of Ma'at-the fundamental order of truth, justice, law, and order that puts gods, mortal pharaohs, and ordinary men and women in their logical and rightful place in the universe. The Egyptian pantheon is unusual in having three gods responsible for death, each with different alignments. Anubis is the lawful neutral god of the afterlife, who judges the souls of the dead. Set is a chaotic evil god of murder, perhaps best known for killing his brother Osiris. And Nephthys is a chaotic good goddess of mourning.

extracted_concepts.definition: A collection of deities representing a fantasy interpretation of ancient Norse religions, originating from a brutal clime and embodying strong leadership and decisive action, suitable for divine characters in Dungeons & Dragons. It includes two main families: the Aesir and the Vanir.

rule_logic.premise: A D&D campaign incorporates fantasy-historical pantheons.
rule_logic.implication: The Norse Pantheon, including its specific deities, alignments, domains, and symbols, is available for player character choices and world-building. It is composed of the Aesir and Vanir families, who are allied against giants.
rule_logic.description_text: Where the land plummets from the snowy hills into the icy fjords below, where the longboats draw up on to the beach, where the glaciers flow forward and retreat with every fall and spring-this is the land of the Vikings, the home of the Norse pantheon. It's a brutal clime, and one that calls for brutal living. The warriors of the land have had to adapt to the harsh conditions in order to survive, but they haven't been too twisted by the needs of their environment. Given the necessity of raiding for food and wealth, it's surprising the mortals turned out as well as they did. Their powers reflect the need these warriors had for strong leadership and decisive action. Thus, they see their deities in every bend of a river, hear them in the crash of the thunder and the booming of the glaciers, and smell them in the smoke of a burning longhouse. The Norse pantheon includes two main families, the Aesir (deities of war and destiny) and the Vanir (gods of fertility and prosperity). Once enemies, these two families are now closely allied against their common enemies, the giants (including the gods Surtur and Thrym).
